sen.j: 長皇子（ながのみこ、生年不詳 - 和銅8年6月4日 (旧暦)（715年7月9日））は飛鳥時代後期から奈良時代初期にかけて活躍した皇族。
sen.e: Naga no miko (year of birth unknown-July 9, 715) was a member of the Imperial family, who came to the fore from the late Asuka period to the early Nara period.
Naga no miko (year of birth unknown - July 9, 715) was a member of the imperial family, who came to the fore from the late Asuka period to the early Nara period.
Naga no miko (year of birth unknown - July 9, 715) was a member of the imperial family, who came to the fore from the late Asuka period to the early Nara period.

sen.j: 父は第40代天武天皇、母は天智天皇皇女の大江皇女。
sen.e: His father was the fortieth Emperor Temmu, and his mother was Oe no himemiko (Princess Oe), the daughter of Emperor Tenchi.
His father was the fortieth Emperor Temmu, and his mother was Oe no Himemiko (Princess Oe), the daughter of Emperor Tenchi.
His father was the fortieth Emperor Tenmu, and his mother was Oe no Himemiko (Princess Oe), the daughter of Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: 同母兄弟には弓削皇子、子女は栗栖王、文室浄三、長田王、文室大市らがいる。
sen.e: Yuge no Miko (Prince Yuge) was his brother (the same father and mother), and Kurosu-o (His Highness Kurosu), FUNYA no Kiyomi, Nagata-o (His Highness Nagata), and FUNYA no Ochi numbered among his children.

Yuge no Miko (Prince Yuge) was his brother (the same father and mother), and Kurosu-o (His Highness Kurosu), FUNYA no Kiyomi, Nagata-o (His Highness Nagata), and FUNYA no Ochi numbered among his children.
Yuge no Miko (Prince Yuge) was his brother (the same father and mother), and Prince Kurusu, FUNYA no Kiyomi, Prince Nagata, and FUNYA no Ochi numbered among his children.

sen.j: 前半生の事績は不明で、記録上の初登場は693年（持統天皇7年）に浄広弐に任じられた時。
sen.e: What kind of achievements he made in the first half of his life is unknown because his name first appears in documents when he was created Joko Second Grade in 693.
The exploits of the first half of his life are unknown because his name first appears in documents when he was made Joko Second Grade in 693.
The exploits of the first half of his life are unknown because his name first appears in documents when he was made Joko Second Grade in 693.

sen.j: その後は順調に出世し、慶雲元年（704年）と和銅7年（714年）にはそれぞれ封戸200戸を加増されている。
sen.e: He continued to advance in the world afterwards, with his fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples) being augmented in 704 and 714 with the additional households of 200 each time.
He subsequently continued to advance his career, with his fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples) being increased by 200 households in 704 and 714.
He subsequently continued to advance his career, with his fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples) being increased by 200 households in 704 and 714.

sen.j: 薨去時の年齢は不明だが、皇子である智努王らの生年から40歳代中盤から50歳代前半と推定される。
sen.e: His age at the time of death is unclear, but it is estimated from the year of the birth of his son Chinu-o (His Highness Chinu), etc. that he died from his mid-forties to early fifties.
His age at the time of death is unclear, but it is estimated from details such as the year of the birth of his son Chinu-o (His Highness Chinu) that he died in his mid-forties to early fifties.
His age at the time of death is unclear, but it is estimated from details such as the year of the birth of his son Prince Chinu that he died in his mid-40's to early 50's.
sen.cmt: 「王」は Prince としました。数字表記変更

sen.j: また、彼をキトラ古墳の被葬者である説も存在している。
sen.e: Incidentally, there is a belief that the person buried in Kitora Tumulus should be Naga no miko.
There is a theory that the person buried in Kitora Tumulus is Naga no Miko.
There is a theory that the person buried in Kitora-kofun Tumulus is Naga no Miko.

sen.j: 続日本紀によれば、天武天皇の第4皇子にあたる。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), Naga no miko was the fourth prince of Emperor Temmu.
According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), Naga no Miko was the fourth son of Emperor Temmu.
According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), Naga no Miko was the fourth son of Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 長皇子の子のうち文室浄三、文室大市は舎人親王薨去後、天平勝宝4年（752年）に臣籍降下し、文屋姓を下賜された（なお、栗栖王の系統は曾孫の助雄がはじめて同姓の下賜を受けた）。
sen.e: Among his children, FUNYA no Kiyomi and FUNYA no Ochi, after the death of Imperial Prince Toneri, became subjects of the state in 752 and were given the surname 'Funya' (Incidentally, as for the Kurosu-o branch, it was not until the generation of his great grandson, Sukeo, that the surname 'Funya' was given to the branch).

Among his children, FUNYA no Kiyomi and FUNYA no Ochi, after the death of Imperial Prince Toneri, became subjects of the state in 752 and were given the surname 'Funya' (As for the Kurosu-o branch, it was not until the generation of his great grandson, Sukeo, that the surname 'Funya' was given to the branch).

Among his children, FUNYA no Kiyomi and FUNYA no Ochi, after the death of Imperial Prince Toneri, became subjects of the state in 752 and were given the surname 'Funya' (As for the Prince Kurusu branch, it was not until the generation of his great grandson, Sukeo, that the surname 'Funya' was given to the branch.)
sen.cmt: Kurosu-o→Prince Kurusuピリオドを括弧内へ移動

sen.j: その後、他の天武系皇族が相次いで政争により粛清された中を生き延びた。
sen.e: Later, the members of the Imperial household related to Emperor Temmu were purged in series due to power struggle, but Naga no miko survived.
The members of the imperial household who were related to Emperor Temmu were successively purged due to a power struggle, but Naga no Miko survived.
The members of the imperial household who were related to Emperor Tenmu were successively purged due to a power struggle, but Kiyomi and Ochi survived.
sen.cmt: Temmu→Tenmu「その後、生き延びた」のはj上記の二人で、Naga no Miko→Kiyomi and Ochi としました。

sen.j: また、実現はしなかったが、神護景雲4年（770年）の称徳天皇崩御時には、吉備真備によって皇嗣候補に推された。
sen.e: Meanwhile, when Emperor Shotoku passed away in 770, Naga no miko was recommended by KIBI no Makibi as a candidate for the Crown Prince, although the plan did not come to fruition.
Meanwhile, when Emperor Shotoku passed away in 770, Naga no Miko was recommended by KIBI no Makibi as a candidate for Crown Prince, although the plan did not come to fruition.
Meanwhile, when Emperor Shotoku passed away in 770, they were recommended by KIBI no Makibi as a candidate for Crown Prince, although the plan did not come to fruition.
sen.cmt: 「長皇子が推された」と訳されていますが、彼は770年にはすでに没しています。これも上記の二人と解釈し、Naga no Miko→they としました。

sen.j: 坂上田村麻呂と共に蝦夷征討に活躍した文室綿麻呂（智努王の孫）や、歌人の文屋康秀（大市王の玄孫）など、文室氏（文屋氏）は皇統が天武系から天智系に戻った後も平安時代初期まで活躍が確認されている。
sen.e: It is confirmed that even after the switch of the Imperial lineage from the branch of Emperor Temmu to the branch of Emperor Tenchi, the flourish of the Funya family continued until the early Heian period, producing FUNYA no Watamaro (the grandson of His Highness Chinu), who, together with SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, played an important role in the subjection of indigenous inhabitants in eastern Japan, and FUNYA no Yasuhide (the great-great-grandson of His Highness Ochi), a poet.

It is confirmed that even after the switch of the Imperial lineage from the branch of Emperor Temmu to the branch of Emperor Tenchi, the prosperity of the Funya family continued until the early Heian period, producing FUNYA no Watamaro (the grandson of His Highness Chinu), who, together with SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, played an important role in the subjugation of indigenous inhabitants in eastern Japan, and FUNYA no Yasuhide (the great-great-grandson of His Highness Ochi), a poet.

It is confirmed that even after the switch of the Imperial lineage from the branch of Emperor Temmu to the branch of Emperor Tenchi, the prosperity of the Funya family continued until the early Heian period, producing FUNYA no Watamaro (the grandson of Prince Chinu), who, together with SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, played an important role in the subjugation of indigenous inhabitants in eastern Japan, and FUNYA no Yasuhide (the great-great-grandson of Prince Ochi), a poet.
sen.cmt: Temmu→Tenmu余分なスペース削除「王」はPrince としました。

sen.j: 万葉集に5首歌が残っている歌人でもある。
sen.e: Naga no miko was also a poet, with the five pieces of his poetry being collected in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).
Naga no miko was also a poet, with five pof his works surviving in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).
Naga no miko was also a poet, with five of his works surviving in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).

sen.j: 前述の文屋康秀とその子の文屋朝康も小倉百人一首歌人の一人だが、それぞれ長皇子からは5代・6代目の子孫にあたる。
sen.e: The above-mentioned FUNYA no Yasuhide and his son FUNYA no Asayasu, are poets selected in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (the Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets), and they were the fifth and sixth descendants of Naga no miko.

The above-mentioned FUNYA no Yasuhide and his son FUNYA no Asayasu are poets selected in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (the Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets), and they were the fifth and sixth descendants of Naga no Miko.

The above-mentioned FUNYA no Yasuhide and his son FUNYA no Asayasu are poets selected in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (the Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets), and they were the fifth and sixth descendants of Naga no Miko.

sen.j: 宵に逢ひて朝面無み隠にか日長き妹が廬りせりけむ
sen.e: Slept together at night/ Said in the morning she was hiding ('nabaru') because she felt bashful/In Nabaru, does she sojourn at an inn?/ It's been long time since she started out
Slept together at night/ Said in the morning she was hiding ('nabaru') because she felt bashful/In Nabaru, does she sojourn at an inn?/ It's been long time since she started out
Slept together at night/ Said in the morning she was hiding ('nabaru') because she felt bashful/In Nabaru, does she sojourn at an inn?/ It's been long time since she started out

sen.j: 霰うつ安良礼松原住吉の弟日娘子と見れど飽かぬかも(706年(慶雲3年)の文武天皇、難波行幸の際に歌った歌。）
sen.e: Covered in a blanket of fog/ Beauty of pine woodland in Sumiyoshi/ Like Courtesan Otohi of Sumiyoshi/ Its beauty never cease to catch my eye (The verses were created in 706 upon Emperor Mommu's visit to Naniwa (Osaka))

Covered in a blanket of fog/ Beauty of pine woodland in Sumiyoshi/ Like Courtesan Otohi of Sumiyoshi/ Its beauty never cease to catch my eye (The verses were created in 706 upon Emperor Mommu's visit to Naniwa (Osaka))

Covered in a blanket of fog/ Beauty of pine woodland in Sumiyoshi/ Like Courtesan Otohi of Sumiyoshi/ Its beauty never cease to catch my eye (The verses were created in 706 upon Emperor Monmu's visit to Naniwa [Osaka])
sen.cmt: Mommu→Monmu括弧内の括弧を[]に変更

sen.j: 我妹子を早見浜風大和なる我まつ椿吹かざるなゆめ
sen.e: Want to see my wife soon ('hayami')/Listen, breeze in Hayami Beach/ Please blow toward pines ('matsu) and camellias ('tsubaki') in Yamato Province ('matsu' and 'tsubaki' are metaphor of 'waiting wife' (matsu tsuma))/ Never fail to reach there

Want to see my wife soon ('hayami')/Listen, breeze in Hayami Beach/ Please blow toward pines ('matsu) and camellias ('tsubaki') in Yamato Province ('matsu' and 'tsubaki' are metaphor of 'waiting wife' (matsu tsuma))/ Never fail to reach there

Want to see my wife soon ('hayami')/Listen, breeze in Hayami Beach/ Please blow toward pines ('matsu') and camellias ('tsubaki') in Yamato Province ('matsu' and 'tsubaki' are metaphor of 'waiting wife' [matsu tsuma])/ Never fail to reach there

sen.j: 秋さらば今も見るごと妻恋ひに鹿鳴かむ山そ高野原の上
sen.e: In autumn/ Like the scenery we see now/ Stag cries for his lover in mountains/ This residence in Takanohara is a place like this
In autumn/ Like the scenery we see now/ Stag cries for his lover in mountains/ This residence in Takanohara is a place like this
In autumn/ Like the scenery we see now/ Stag cries for his lover in mountains/ This residence in Takanohara is a place like this

sen.j: 丹生の川瀬は渡らずてゆくゆくと恋痛し我が弟いで通ひ来ね
sen.e: Please do not cross the River Nifu/ Instead, walk along the river/My dear younger brother in the pain of love/ Please come here
Please do not cross the River Nifu/ Instead, walk along the river/My dear younger brother in the pain of love/ Please come here
Please do not cross the River Nifu/ Instead, walk along the river/My dear younger brother in the pain of love/ Please come here
